dialogue.raw_text: Obviously, Donald didn't feel that way or he wouldn't have left the team to me. And I was more than showgirl. I was a dancer. Now, I know some of you have doubts about my ability to run this franchise. God help you if I ever find out about it.

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.

direction.raw_text: compressing and detailing the progress of spring training. We see: A) Vaughn on the pitcher's mound. A tin replica of a batter has been set up at home plate and rope stretched across the plate to delineate the strike zone. Vaughn fires a pitch and hits the tin batter in the hip, leaving a dent in him. B) Cerrano in the batting cage, flailing away in futility at several curve balls. C) HAYES doing push-ups at night. He's the only one left on the field, except Temple, who supervises. D) TAYLOR doing the "scramble" drill -- blocking down balls purposely thrown in the dirt, one after another. When it ends, he can hardly get to his feet. E) CERRANO waving a ten-foot BOA CONSTRICTOR in the sign of the cross in front of his locker before opening it. No red tag greets him. Hayes watches from a safe distance. F) VAUGHN holding a mirror under the vents on his locker door to get a peek inside to see if there's a red tag there. G) DORN taking a hard ground ball off the chest. Brown applauds. Dorn is pissed. H) VAUGHN throwing at the "ropes" again. The tin batter is dented in every conceivable place now. Vaughn whips in another fast ball. This one hits the tin man in the head, knocking it completely off. I) TAYLOR in an exhibition game, attempting to throw out a base stealer. Jake springs out of his crouch and fires down to second -- on a bounce. The ball skips into center field. J) HAYES also in an exhibition game, swinging at a pitch and popping it up behind the plate. He just drops in his tracks and starts to do push-ups as the catcher makes the catch behind him. K) CERRANO flailing away again at a curve ball. This and the remaining shots are all in exhibition games. L) HAYES waving a ten-inch garter snake in front of his locker. Even at this size we can tell it scares the hell out of him, but it works its magic. No red tag. M) VAUGHN with a runner on third, winding up and throwing a pitch four feet over Taylor's head. The run scores. N) HAYES attempting to steal second. He goes into a hell-bent-for- leather head first slide. Unfortunately, he comes up two feet short of the base. The second baseman, who's waiting for him with the ball, makes a motion for him to keep coming. Hayes flips him the bird. O) LOU BROWN on the bench. He turns to Pepper with a look that says, "Can you believe this shit?" P) TAYLOR waiting for a throw at the plate. Just as he's about to catch it, the runner knocks him flat. Q) BROWN his head in his hands. As Taylor gets up and goes to the wrong dugout, the MONTAGE ENDS.
direction.name: direction

He sprays a patch of white paint on the locker door from a spray can, draws a symbol door. No tag. He kisses the snake, leaving some white paint on his lips, like a kid who's just had a glass of milk. Taylor, exhausted from the game, lifts his latch and peers inside. He's made it, too. Cerrano offers a hand. Taylor shakes it and breaks a weary smile.

direction.raw_text: Taylor points to the left field stands. He imagines a pitch coming in, takes a mighty swing and admires the flight of the imaginary ball as it arches high in the mid-day sky, landing deep in the left field seats. Breaking into his home run trot, he circles the bases, slapping the third base coach's hand and exchanging low fives with his teamates as he reaches the plate. Suddenly, his reverie is interrupted by the sound of applause. He turns and looks in the dugout, where Hayes and Vaughn are giving him a hand.

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not much for inspirational addresses. I just wanta point out that every newspaper in the country has picked us to finish last. The local press thinks we'd save everybody a lot of time and trouble if we just went out and shot ourselves. Me, I like to waste sportswriters' time so I'm for hangin' around and seein' if we can give all these guys a nice big shitburger to eat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Aren't we gonna have a prayer? I mean we're not all savages like Cerrano.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You guys go ahead. I belong to the church of three-run homers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, let's bow our heads.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Have to wake up bats.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Dear Lord, we ask...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The stands are nearly empty. Of the fans who have showed up, many wear doormats around their necks. Bobby, Vic, Johnny and Thelma, our four fans from the diner, sit alone in the vast expanse of the centerfield bleachers. All four wear Indian head dresses and have war paint on their faces. The three men each have tom-toms. Thelma works on her needlepoint.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You read the Plain Dealer today? They said this is gonna be the worst Indian team we've had in years.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Everybody laughs at the Indians now, but there were other times. Even won the Series in '48. Then Willie Mays made that catch on Vic Wertz in the '54 Series and Cleveland's never been the same since.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: As the Indians go so goes Cleveland, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If we ever lost the Indians, Cleveland would die.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We get our fist glimpse of HARRY DOYLE, the Indians' 55-year- old radio announcer. Harry's never walked past a bar in anger. He's been with the Indians through thin and thinner.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle leans out the press box window with his mike, trying to pick up the sound of a couple guys CLAPPING down below.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle takes a hit of his spiked Coke.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (on the air) Hello, everybody, Harry Doyle here, welcoming all you Friends of the Feather to another season of Indians baseball. (pouring some Jack Daniels in his Coke) A lotta new faces for the tribe this year, as they take on the defending American League champs, the New York Yankees. And listen to the roar of the crowd as the Indians takes the field!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, sir, they love this club here in Cleveland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: flies out to Hayes, who makes a "basket" catch a la Willie Mays.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: DOWN ON THE FIELD A YANKEE HITTER

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) High fly ball, centerfield. Hayes under it now... Oh, makes a basket catch, Willie Mays style, and the side is retired.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The team comes in off the field to much enthusiasm and back- slapping.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: All right, way to look, way to look. Nice catch, Hayes. Don't ever fuckin' do it again. Okay, let's get it goin'!
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bottom of the first, Willie Mays Hayes to lead it off for the tribe.
direction.name: direction

result.heading: DOYLE IN THE PRESS BOX DOYLE

direction.raw_text: going through his warmup routine at the plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hayes is in the batter's box now. The Yankee pitcher winds and fires. Hayes swings and hits a little dribbler toward the second baseman, who races in and scoops it up bare-handed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle leans out the window again trying to pick up some cheering.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) A lotta people say you can tell how a season's gonna go by the first hitter of the year. In the last fifteen years, the Indians have never had the season lead-off hitter reach base.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Hot shot toward the hole. Rudia knocks it down, gets up, fires to first. Too late! Hayes beats it!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: And so the string is broken. Maybe things will turn around a little for the Indians this year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Our four fans (from here on known as the Bleacher Band), overjoyed by Hayes' hit, start beating the tom-toms and singing a fight song they've composed called "In the Land Of Burning Waters" to the tune of the old Hamms Beer jingle.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In the land of burning waters, waters Lurks the Injun nine, oh so fine, we Love those mighty Redmen, Turn their foes to dead men, Ummmmm.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: as Hayes comes back to the bag, where the Yankee FIRST BASEMAN is waiting for him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hayes reaches in his back pocket and pulls out one of the pairs of black leather gloves he bought earlier.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hayes takes his lead-off and crouches, ready to steal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hayes looks down at his shoe. It's not untied. He notices too late that the PITCHER is throwing over to pick him off.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hayes dives back for the bag, but never gets there; his face smashing up against the First Baseman's glove, which is already holding the ball.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hayes lies in the dust humiliated.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle takes a long pull on his Coke and we GO INTO A MONTAGE depicting the Indians' progressive disintegration in this game. We see: A) THREE FIELDERS converging on a short pop fly into left field. They all collide and go down in a heap as the ball drops untouched. B) DORN playing a grounder off his hip. He fumbles it, picks it up, fumbles it again. No play. C) TAYLOR crouched behind the plate, but up off his haunches, ready to throw. We hear the voice of his thoughts.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The runner on first takes off as the pitch comes in. Taylor catches the ball and fires down to second. The ball sails three feet over the second baseman's head and on into center field. Taylor stands there, disgusted.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: D) CERRANO striking out on a curve ball. He bawls his bat out on the way to the dugout. E) THE THREE FIELDERS we saw before, converging on another pop fly into short left. This time all three dive off at the last instant to avoid a collision. Once again the ball drops untouched.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Showed some real power on that one, Slugger.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I plan to get at least a double out of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) And now Hayes is putting on a pair of black gloves, sending a little message to the Yankees.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to the First Baseman) Bought a hundred of these, one for each base I plan to steal. Excuse me, here, I gotta take my first step toward the Hall of Fame.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You look real sharp, but you'll never steal second with your shoe untied.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Brewster, quick move to first...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) He got him. Hayes is picked off.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice base running, dildo. Hard to get your thumb out of your ass with the gloves on.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, so much for that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Guy's goin'. Gotta be goin'... get the throw up. Don't bounce the damn ball.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nice throw, dickhead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: It shows Yankees 4, Indians 0 after five innings.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: There are two empty Coca-Cola cups near the mike. He's working on a third.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn stands on the mound rubbing up the baseball with the same intensity we saw in the locker room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn nods and continues to grind the ball as Pepper and Taylor leave. The Yankee Hitter steps in. Vaughn winds and fires a screamer. Taylor has to leap high to come down with it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The Yankee Hitter is slightly unnerved by this pitch.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Top of the sixth. Rookie sensation, Ricky Vaughn, on to pitch now. You can close the book on Winters...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy does it, Ricky. We're only four down. We're still in this thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry if you're off the plate on a few pitches. Doesn't hurt to put the fear of God in a hitter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) First pitch is a little high...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This guy kinda wild?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I figure you got a 30% chance to survive this at bat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to the Yankee hitter. It's outside.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Ball four.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to a SECOND YANKEE HITTER. It's low.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Ball eight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: to a THIRD YANKEE HITTER. He has to jump over it.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Low, and Vaughn has walked the bases loaded on twelve straight pitches. By the laws of probability, you'd think one of those coulda drifted over the plate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bobby gives the downbeat and, in honor of Vaughn, the three men stand to pound out a version of "Wild Thing" on the tom- toms. Bobby does the vocal.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Pepper has reached the mound...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn nods. He's plenty upset with himself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He gives Vaughn a pat on the butt, and goes back to the dugout. The Yankee hitter, HAYWOOD, stands in. He's the first baseman who tagged Hayes out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn, determined to throw a strike, winds and delivers. The ball is a perfect strike, right down the middle. Haywood crushes it to deep left field. Vaughn drops his head, not even bothering to look.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The ball lands in the second deck; a grand slam home run.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn paces around on the mound, rubbing up the ball. The next hitter, COLEMAN, steps in. Vaughn gets up on the rubber, his face set. He winds up and fires one right into Coleman's back. Coleman goes down in a hurry.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Both benches are up on the dugout steps ready to come out. The only thing holding them back is that Coleman is being tended to by the trainer. The home plate umpire thumbs Vaughn out of the game. Vaughn comes down to protest, but Pepper quickly grabs him and hurries him off the field.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Coleman finally gets to his feet, still a little shaken. He looks around for Vaughn, but he's already disappeared into the dugout. Coleman walks down to first under his own power. Brown signals for a new pitcher and the players on both sides begin to return to the benches.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wild thing, You make my heart sing, You walk everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay kid. I think we got 'em scared enough now. Time to get a few of 'em out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just relax, and keep the arm up on top. Gotta throw strikes. No place at the inn for this guy.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Taylor, what you doin' back up here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Couldn't cut it in the Mexican League.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, shit...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (to Brown) Looked like a strike anyway. You want me to go get him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, let's see how he reacts.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Interesting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At least he hit what he was aimin' at.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think you can go get him now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, kid. As soon as Coleman gets up, he's gonna be lookin' for you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: walking alone down the tunnel to the locker room. He angrily knocks one of the overhead light bulbs out with his glove.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He now has five empty cups next to the mike, plus a near- empty bottle of Jack Daniel's.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that Doyle passes out on his face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: So, a tough start for the Erie warriors, as they drop a heartbreaker to the Yankees, nine to nothing. The Post Game Show was brought to you by... (searching for the paper) Christ. I can't find it. The hell with it. This is Harry Doyle saying good night, everybody, and Happy Hunting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: in her private box at the stadium. With her are Donovan and Butler.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We GO TO Donovan. He watches Rachel go in disgust.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (getting up to leave) We're off to a good start, gentlemen. Let's keep it up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Taylor, Hayes and Vaughn are in a booth, having a beer. Vaughn is still in a funk.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn nods slowly.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn just looks at Taylor a second and then smiles in spite of himself.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: God, I was horse shit tonight.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Only thing you got to be sorry about was hittin' Coleman.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: If you wanted to send a message, it shoulda been to Haywood. He hit the damn homer. Coleman was just picking his nose in the on-deck circle.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget the other stuff. It coulda happened to anybody. Besides, Haywood didn't hit it that good. That ball wouldn't have been out of a lotta parks.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh yeh, name one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (after a pause) Yellowstone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shit...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We see Taylor walking up the steps and through the massive front door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We PICK UP Taylor making his way past the circulation desk. He glances around and finds what he's looking for: Lynn, talking to one of the reference librarians. She finishes her conversation and turns, to find herself face to face with Taylor. She's wearing her tortoise-shell glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn starts to walk. We'll FOLLOW them as they make their way through the library. Lynn tries to keep the conversation hushed. Taylor could give a shit.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jake suppresses a smile.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn stops and turns to face him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor is momentarily floored by the revelation.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're in the large reading room now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With this the whole reading room turns around and stares at her. Lynn is mortified by her outburst. Taylor tries to smooth it over.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Nice job, Jake. Lynn is still mortified.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Most of the hands in the room shoot up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn starts off for her office door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn continues on into her office. As the door closes, we GO TO Taylor's forlorn face.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (hushed) Jake, you shouldn't have come here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was wonderin' why you'd give an old friend a bum phone number.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let's talk in my office, okay?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't wanna talk in your office.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I told you I don't think it's a good idea for us to see each other.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Why not?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We don't have anything in common. Sometimes I wonder if we ever did.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talkin' about? We were both athletes, world class, hot for each other. What more can you have in common?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I stopped bein' an athlete three years ago. Books are my life now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you dare laugh, Jake. In two years I've put together one of the best special collections departments in the country.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So what is it? You're still sore I never read Moby Dick?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You never read anything I asked you to.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not like what's-his-name at the restaurant?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: His name is Tom, and keep your voice down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do ya see in this guy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's stable. He's intelligent... and I've never found him in bed with a stewardess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's 'cause no stewardess would have him. Wouldn't you rather be with somebody who's in demand?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just like always, you don't take anything seriously. Everything's a joke to you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Lynn, for Christ sake, I'm just tryin' to loosen things up a little. I'm gettin' frostbite here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tom and I are getting married in the fall.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What? That's crazy, Lynn. I got plans for us.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking again) What plans?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was gonna play another a year or two, then we go to Hawaii, and have a couple kids who grow up to be Olympic champions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stopping again) How can you think stuff like that? I haven't seen you in two years. You never even wrote me a letter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm sorry, Lynn, but I wasn't exactly proud of my situation. C'mon, you didn't think about me at all since I been gone?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking again) Not so loud, Jake.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Remember the three nights we spent on the beach in Vera Cruz? You have nights like that with Mr. Briefcase?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (stopping again) What about the night you had in Detroit with Miss Dairy Queen?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What was I supposed to do? She bet me fifty bucks she had a better body than you. I had to defend your honor.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (whirling on him and exploding) What a bunch of bullshit! (exasperated) I have a much better body than she does.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (addressing the library patrons) She's right. Take it from me, she really does. I mean Miss Dairy Queen has quantity, I give her that, but the, ah, quality just isn't there.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How many think Lynn oughta give me another shot?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The ayes have it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (walking off again) You haven't changed at all, have you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm afraid I have or I wouldn't be here. C'mon, Lynn, I don't wanna do time for things that happened years ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (turning back to him) I'm sorry, Jake. You'll always be the little boy who wouldn't grow up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lynn, wait...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Rachel is in closed-door session with Donovan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: As Donovan wonders what she means by that, we...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: A quarter of the season's gone, we're 15 and 24, seven games out of first. Our attendance is just below 180,000. That's bad, but not bad enough.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Projected over the whole season, we stand to wind up 36 games under .500 and 28 out of first. That should be bad enough for anybody.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: We finished 24 out last year and still drew 890,000. When school's out for the summer, attendance is liable to rise. Plus, this team is showing signs of improvement. I didn't think we'd win 15 games all year. Any ideas?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: On how we can get worse? (sarcastic) How about a series of fines for good play? Maybe a $30,000 bonus to the guy chosen Least Valuable Player.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This is no laughing matter, Donovan. (pause) I think maybe the problem is we're coddling these guys too much.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We PICK UP Taylor, Hayes, Vaughn and the other Indians coming down a corridor to their plane.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They come through the gate where they see two American Airlines jets on the tarmac.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The gateman points off-screen. Suddenly, an old DC-3, with the Indian logo on it, pulls into frame.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's with this? We never leave from this terminal.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe the other one's jammed up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (pointing to the jets) Which one is ours?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: This one was obviously bought from the military. The seats are 40's Army issue, and the ribs of the fuselage are exposed. The plane is bobbing and lurching through a ferocious storm.
direction.name: direction

direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Hayes sits petrified in his chair, his knuckles whitening on the arm rest.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What is this, Lou?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Front office says it's an economy measure, 'cause we're not drawin' good.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, they certainly have spared every expense.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh, so now you come around. (pointing up) He's not fooled.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Call the stewardess, Vaughn. I need one of those bags.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There aren't any stewardesses.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I wonder if there's any pilots.

dialogue.raw_text: Two down, top of the ninth. Last chance for the red and blue.

dialogue.raw_text: So, the Sons of Geronimo, still suffering a bit from propeller lag, are nipped by the Tigers tonight, 7 to 0. The only excitement for the tribe provided by Rick Vaughn who set an American League record by throwing four wild pitches in one inning. Congratulations, Rick. For the Tigers, 5 runs, 9 hits, and no errors. For the Indians, one run, and let's see, one hit. (to his Stat Man) Is that all we got, one fucking hit?

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry about it. Nobody's listening anyway.

dialogue.raw_text: Who you got lined up tonight?

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He's kinda cute. They say he could be a big star.

dialogue.raw_text: What are you talkin' about? He couldn't find the plate if it was magnetized. He won't last the year.

dialogue.raw_text: (grabbing her) Wait a minute, you're with me.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't remember you makin' any date.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Since when do I have to make a date? Who's been showin' you this town the last three years?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ancient history, Rodger. I gotta look out for myself now. I don't have to be a slave to no .235 hitter.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: pulls away and heads for the jukebox as Dorn seethes. She punches a button and we hear X's version of "WILD THING."
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: sashays right up to Vaughn in time with the music.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Wild Thing, you make my heart sing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: knows how to make the big entrance. Vaughn's slightly overwhelmed.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: taking this all in from across the room. Taylor comes up next to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Guess we're over with, eh, Dorn?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Speak for yourself, Taylor. I got a couple good years left.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We PICK UP Taylor in his seat, glasses on, reading something by the light of a flashlight rigged up to the back of his seat. We MOVE to reveal it -- the Classics Illustrated comic book of "Moby Dick." Hayes wanders by, an air-sick bag hanging around his neck.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor indicates a stack of Classic Comics next to him.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: "Moby Dick?" What is that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's one of the masterpieces of American literature, that's all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Lynn put you on to this?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Long time ago.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, we're goin' to a club tonight. You wanna come along?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, I got some more reading to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What, you got a test or somethin'? Why don't you just go over and see her? Maybe she'll let you slide on a couple of these.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I might if I knew where she lives.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Easy. Tail her home from the library.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You mean sit in a car and wait for her to come out? That's kinda juvenile, don't you think?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (as if that had anything to do with it) Yeh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Taylor sits in his car, across the street from the employee entrance of the library. He scrunches down a bit as Lynn comes out of the building and heads for her car. She gets in and we...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: driving through the city with Taylor following at a discrete distance. Finally, Lynn pulls up outside an expensive-looking townhouse. Taylor pulls up further down the street and watches her go inside, debating whether to go in after her.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor's having a beer, still trying to decide whether to go see her or not.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: pulling up outside the townhouse he saw Lynn go into. He goes up the stairs and knocks on the door. Lynn answers, looking more dressed up than when she left the library. She's surprised to see Taylor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Lynn can answer, Tom appears at the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Before Taylor can beg off further, Tom ushers him inside and closes the door. In the room are two other couples: ARTHUR HOLLOWAY, a senior partner in Tom's firm and his wife CLAIRE, and BRENT BOWDEN, another lawyer in the firm and a contemporary of Tom's. His wife is JANICE. This is a very upscale group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Polite nods from the group, except for Janice, who seems somewhat intrigued.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor sticks out his hand. Tom's not sure whether Taylor's putting him on or not. He shakes anyway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom goes off to get the beer.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom clinks his glass with Jake's beer, the slight condescension in his manner not lost on Taylor. Lynn is uncomfortable with this whole situation. Janice moves a bit closer to Taylor. It's obvious she finds him attractive.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn is irritated by Janice's directness.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom and the others react as if Taylor's just announced a death in the family.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Everyone is somewhat surprised by Lynn's quick defense of Taylor, including Lynn herself.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Jack just nods. He never heard of it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn's eyes drop to the floor.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: A tense silence settles on the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor exchanges a quick glance with Lynn and heads for the door.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom accompanies Taylor to the door, out of earshot of the others.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Tom sticks out his hand. The two men shake to keep up appearances for their onlookers across the room.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Look, Lynn, I'm sorry I followed you home but I wanna...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (hurried) This isn't my place...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Whose place is it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Who's there, love? (spying Taylor) Oh, Mr. Taylor, right? (pointedly) I remember you from the restaurant. Lynn's told me a lot about you. Why don't you come in for a while?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nah, that's o.k., I got some things to do...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, he's gotta be goin'...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, really, come on in for a drink.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Excuse me, everybody, this is Jake Taylor. (making the intros) Jake, Arthur and Claire Holloway Brent and Janice Bowden. Jake is a professional baseball player.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: So, Jake, what brings you here this evening?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ah, just had a couple books I wanted to discuss with Lynn. I thought this was her place.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, it soon will be.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, I heard you guys were engaged. Congratulations.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thank you. What can I get you to drink?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Beer'll be fine.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What team do you play for, Jake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The Indians.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here in Cleveland? I didn't know they still had a team.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, we have uniforms and everything. It's really great.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (handing Jake his beer) They're last right now, but hopefully moving up, eh, Jake?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm told that baseball players make very good salaries these days.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That depends on how good they are, I guess.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How good are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I make the League minimum.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: He was one of the best in baseball until he had problems with his knees.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What are you going to do when your career ends? I mean you can't play baseball forever, can you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Somethin'll come up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Will it?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know, I was thinkin' of goin' to Hawaii, and having a couple of kids who grow up to be Olympic champions.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Oh really. In what event?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Swimming. Maybe the two hundred meter Individual Medley. I figure it oughta be big by then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You got the girl picked out?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I did, but I wasn't smart enough to hold on to her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You used to be an athlete, didn't you, Lynn?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (not wanting to pursue it) Yes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What did you do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (reluctant) Two Hundred Individual medley.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Alternate on the '80 Olympic Team.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I gotta be goin'. Nice to have met you all.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Let me walk you out.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Thanks for the beer.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't mention it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll let you know if I land a good job. I know you're concerned about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, well, I just wanted Lynn to know what she would've had ahead of her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Stay away from her.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (smiling) Suck my dick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Vaughn and Hayes are watching a soap opera on an old black and white TV. Pepper pops his head in.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn looks somewhat apprehensively at Hayes.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Lou wants to see you down at the office, Rick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brown is lost in thought at his desk. Vaughn appears at the door like a boy expecting a spanking.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn comes in and takes a seat. He's worried.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn nods contritely.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn looks at the picture on the wall. He squints slightly. Brown notices it.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brown quickly prints some big letters on a legal pad and goes to stand about fifteen feet from Vaughn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn balks a second and then concentrates on the pad, squinting. Unsettled, he squints harder. He even tries closing one eye.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn shakes his head no.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon in, Rick.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rick, I'm not gonna beat around the bush here. You got a great arm, one of the best I've ever seen, but your control hasn't come around like we hoped it would.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Now, there are a lotta pitchers that started out wild and, after workin' it out in the minors, for a while, went on to great careers. (pointing to a picture on the wall) Take Sandy Koufax there...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What about Koufax?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Never mind Koufax.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Read these letters, starting at the top.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can't read it, can you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You gonna send me to the minors?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Nope.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor, Hayes, Vaughn and the others are dressing out for the game. Vaughn is wearing his glasses.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Meanwhile, Cerrano is sharpening a long knife at his locker.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Cerrano pulls the unborn chicken out of his pocket -- a common store bought egg. Harris is a little embarrassed at his outburst. Cerrano touches the egg to his forehead, then places it on his altar. In one swift motion he slams the knife down on it, cutting it into two perfect halves. Taylor and the others are agape at a knife sharp enough to do this. As the yolk spreads out on the altar, Brown emerges from his office.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: The locker room quickly empties, leaving one man behind -- Harris. He looks around to make sure everyone is gone, then tiptoes over to Cerrano's locker. Screwing up his courage, he picks up Jo-Buu's cup of gin.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: He bolts it down, then backs into the middle of the room, waiting at the ready, as if half-expecting a bolt of lightning. When nothing happens, he gloats at the fetish doll in triumph.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: These things make me look ridiculous.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Drop in the bucket, Vaughn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gin and cigarettes not enough for Jo- Buu. I still can no hit curva ball for sheet. I hafta make a sacrifice to him.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sacrifice? You mean like something living?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Si. I kill unborn children.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not while I'm here you're not. That's murder.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: All right, let's hit the field.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Here's looking at ya, Jo-Buu.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: strutting out of the dugout, feeling like a million bucks. As he emerges onto the field, a Hitter in the batting cage swings and misses, the bat slipping out of his hands. Away it flies, whirling off down the third base line in a wide arc. It hits Harris in the back of the head and knocks him cold.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: watching the game from the dugout, a zip-lock baggie full of ice-cubes strapped to his head.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) We're in the ninth, two down, man on first and the Indians clinging to a one run lead. VAUGHAN, one out away from his first major league victory...
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn, wearing his new glasses, paces the mound nervously. He goes to the rosin bag, wipes his brow, shakes out his arm. Finally up on the rubber, he gets the sign from Taylor, goes to his stretch, checks the runner and fires to the plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: swings and hits a grounder between third and short. Dorn moves to his left, but the ball goes past his glove and into left field. There is some question as to whether Dorn really gave it a full effort.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn stomps around on the mound, obviously upset. He glares at Dorn a beat before getting back on the mound. Dorn's face is non-commital. Brown paces in the dugout.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle downs a little more rum and coke in the press box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle imitates the sound of a crowd cheering with his own voice, punctuated by whistles and clapping.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Bouncing ball, Dorn can't get to it, into left field, base hit. Clarke digging around second, he'll make it to third, and the A's have runners at the corners.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You want me to go get him?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: No, he's come this far. Let's see if he can finish it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Vaughn in a little trouble here, but I'll tell ya, these Cleveland fans are great. Listen to them get behind Vaughn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Thelma calmly knits her blanket with the scores of all the Indians' games stitched into it, the Madame La Farge of Cleveland. The boys, however, are a little restless.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: We need some defense here. Maybe we oughta do a wave.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: C'mon, Indians don't do waves. Let's keep this thing pure.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What harm could it do?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The next Oakland hitter, steps in. Taylor flashes a sign. Vaughn comes to the stretch and delivers. High, ball one. The runner on first goes down to second without a throw, the pitch being too tough to handle.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor walks out in front of the plate to throw the ball back to Vaughn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor goes back behind the dish. Vaughn gets up on the rubber. He winds and comes to the plate. Way high this time.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Doyle imitates the sound of a crowd booing. Taylor, meanwhile, has gone out to the mound.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn nods.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor starts back toward the plate, and then stops.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn permits himself a little smile and release from the tension. Taylor smiles back, and trots off toward the plate.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) Runner goes, high, Taylor has no play. The go-ahead and potential winning run is in scoring position.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget the runners, Ricky, get this guy at the plate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: High ball two, and the crowd doesn't like that call one bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Okay, let's get nasty here, Rick. You know he's lookin' for this pitch. Gotta come up with somethin' studly.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fuckin' Dorn. Game shoulda been over by now. Dorn coulda had that ball. He tanked it on purpose.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: This isn't the California Penal League, Vaughn. We're professionals here. We don't tank a play for personal reasons, so cut the crybaby shit. You've pitched a helluva game. You wanna finish it, don't ya?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Can you give me a strike on this pitch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, but I don't know if there'll be much on it. My arm feels like jello.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just make sure it's over the plate. I want him to swing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The last time I did that, the guy hit one that hasn't landed yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't worry, I'll take care of it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By the way, I been meaning to ask you. Why'd you steal that car?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was bored.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Next time you might think about takin' in a movie or somethin'.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bobby and Vic are doing a two-man wave. When one sits down, the other stands up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: has settled in behind the plate now. He starts talking to the batter, Rexman.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rexman shoots Taylor a wicked glance.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rexman, slightly irritated, backs out of the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rexman gets back in the box.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rexman is trying to ignore Taylor, but failing badly. Taylor flashes a sign to Vaughn. Vaughn goes into his windup.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn releases his pitch.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Rexman, completely unnerved, takes a feeble swing and hits a high pop-up out in front of the plate.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor moves out two steps and makes the catch easily, ending the game. Taylor rushes out to congratulate Vaughn. The players exchange handshakes and high fives, as Brown watches from the dugout.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Helluva situation we got goin' here, huh, Rexman? Two on, two out, you're down by a run in the ninth. You got a chance to be a hero on national television, so whatever you do, don't blow it. They'll be callin' you a gutless choke artist all over America.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're a free agent at the end of the year. Not much demand for gutless choke artists. What are you hittin' now? .230? .240?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, nice average. Uh oh, on second thought, that still means you got a seven outta ten chance of goin' in the dumper.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Shut up, will ya, Taylor?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, I can understand not wantin' to talk about baseball when your nuts are in a vice like this.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: By the way, I saw your wife at the Capri Lounge last night. Hell of a dancer. You must be very proud.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: But that guy she was with... I mean I'm sure he's a close personal friend of yours and all, but tell me...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: ...Why was he wearing her panties on his head?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Uh oh, Rexie, I don't think that one's got the distance. Maybe if the wind comes up.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's startin' to come together, Pepper. It's startin' to come together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Taylor pulls up outside and walks up to the door. Suzanne, Dorn's wife, answers.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We FOLLOW Taylor into the luxurious den, where we find Dorn watching his wide screen TV in a smoking jacket.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Dorn looks at Taylor for some sign that he's kidding. He doesn't get one. Taylor turns and walks on out, as we go to Dorn's stunned face. Suzanne walks in with a tray.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Oh hi, Jake, how are you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Fine, Suzanne, can I have a quick word with Rodger?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, c'mon in, he's in the den. I'll get some coffee.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, Jake, old boy, what brings you out here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just wanta tell ya somethin', but I didn't want to do it in front of the whole team.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sure, go ahead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (like nails) I don't know what your problem is, but... (bending close to Dorn) ...if I ever see you tank another play like you did tonight, I'll cut off your nuts and stuff 'em down your fuckin' throat.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Coffee anybody?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Indians are undressing after practice.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Why the hell are we havin' practice during the All-Star break?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I heard the Big Lady upstairs ordered it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's hotter than shit in here. What happened to the air conditioning?
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: We go to Brown, naked and dragging from the heat. He approaches the whirlpool and turns on the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brown flips on a switch. The whirlpool makes some grinding noises and then quits altogether.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Harris shouts over from the showers where he's just turned on the water.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brown is stopped short by the sight of Rachel Phelps standing in the middle of the locker room as various unclad players dive for cover.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Immediately, 30 arms shoot up behind her in the Italian "up- yours" gesture. She turns around, but by then the players have quickly returned to normal positions.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: With that, Rachel turns and walks out. Brown and the others can only watch her go.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (to Dorn) Oh man, this old body can use a soak.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget it. It's not workin' again.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Damn it, I thought they were gonna replace this thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, there's no hot water in here.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She's at it again. I've had it with this nickel and dime stuff. (storming out of the training room) I'm gonna get the Bitch on the phone.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wanted to see the Bitch?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Don't you think you oughta cover yourself with a towel first, Mr. Brown?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: There aren't any towels, and I'm too old to be diving under benches.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, I can take it if you can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What happened to the new whirlpool we were supposed to get?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Revenue problems have forced us to cut back on equipment. We'll simply have to fix the old one.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You fixed it six times already. And now there's no hot water in the showers.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: The pipes in this building are old and rusted. We're replacing them, but it's a long, expensive process.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How am I supposed to keep my players healthy with cold water and no therapy equipment?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your players will just have to get a little tougher. What are they, a bunch of pansies?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Over 162 games even tough guys get sprains, sore arms, muscle pulls...
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: It's only temporary. Besides, these guys weren't playing that good when the equipment was workin'. If I could get anybody to come and watch this team, none of this would be necessary. You oughta be grateful I can still pay your salaries.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Sequence omitted from original script.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On the air.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: In case you haven't noticed, and judging by attendance, you haven't, the Indians, that thought-to-be hopeless collection of has-been's and never-will-be's is actually approaching the .500 mark, and with it, semi-respectability. Nothing to write home about, to be sure, but at least we don't have to cover our eyes.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Bobby, Vic and Johnny are at the counter.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ya know, they could be a lot worse.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The Business Executive is talking with a friend while working out on the Nautilus machines.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ya know, I may have underestimated this team a bit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The two Longshoremen again.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Ya know, these guys aren't so fuckin' bad.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The two Groundskeepers are repairing the pitcher's mound.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (in subtitles) They're still shitty.

direction.raw_text: leaving her seat and starting up the aisle. Taylor comes up the stairs from the locker room, still in full uniform. He emerges onto the box level to see Lynn disappearing down the ramp toward the parking lot.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: in the parking lot. As she goes to unlock her car, Taylor looks around hurriedly for some kind of vehicle to follow her in. He bangs on the bullpen gates and is admitted by the guard. Inside is the Bullpen car, a souped-up golf cart with a body shaped like a batting helmet. Taylor hops in and roars out after Lynn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn comes out of the dressing room into the pool area, deserted this time of night. She wears a racing suit, but lets her hair hang free. The pool glows like a sheet of emerald glass. She shakes down a beat, curls her toes around the coping, slowly bends at the waist, and then launches into a full-out racing dive. We watch as she swims a 100 yard individual medley; first the butterfly, then the backstroke, breaststroke and finally freestyle. We condense the time, of course, SHOOTING some underwater, some SLO-MO, as she knives through the water, her hair flowing behind her, an athlete alone with her medium. The SEQUENCE should convey not only the grace of her strokes and her athletic ability, but the fluid beauty of swimming, its synthesis of power and form. As she begins the freestyle leg, another body appears in the pool next to her. It's Jake, and he's racing her the final lap. She immediately responds to the challenge, digging harder, picking up her kick. They go neck and neck for 20 yards, but Lynn has one more gear and touches him by half a body length at the wall. Both are winded.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: You still got that great kick. Just like the first time I ever saw you.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You follow me here too?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh, what did you want to see me about?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You wouldn't have been at the game if you didn't want to see me about something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting out of the pool) I just wanted to see you play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How was I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You looked good, but you oughta open your stance a little. They're pitching you inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll try that. You wanna have some dinner?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sorry, I already ate.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Right. I forgot your life is different now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (getting out of the pool) Thanks for the race.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (watching her go) Anytime.

direction.raw_text: Driving through the city on her way home. Lynn glances in the rear-view mirror and spots Taylor following her. She smiles to herself. Taylor, of course, thinks he's gone undetected. We begin a SHORT SEQUENCE during which Lynn tries to lose Taylor in a chase through Cleveland, car vs. batting helmet. The logistics will have to be worked out in Cleveland, but suffice it to say, by the end of the chase she appears to have ditched him.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn comes up the stairs, unlocks the apartment door and steps inside. There's no particular urgency. She feels sure she's shaken Taylor. The apartment is full of packing boxes. Tired from the chase, Lynn drops her bag on a box and slumps down on the couch. It's obvious she's not all that happy to have lost Taylor. She goes to the window and looks down to the street for some sign of him. Seeing nothing, she turns away from the window disappointed, and starts back to the couch, when something stops her. It's Taylor, standing in the doorway.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor gives a perfunctory nod. They look at each other a second. There's still plenty there. Taylor begins to come toward her. We hear his cleats on the floor. She backs off, but not with real conviction.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn looks at him a long beat.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Lynn is backed up against a desk now. She could move out but doesn't.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor comes forward to kiss her, tentatively at first. Their conversation is interwoven with the slowly deepening intensity of their kissing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: They're unbuttoning each other's shirts now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Their shirts are off now.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor's spikes come down across her skirt, catching in the material, ripping it from her body and pinning it to the wood floor. Taylor steps out of the shoe and whisks Lynn OUT OF FRAME. We hold on the skirt, nailed to the floor by the cleats.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Whose place are we at this time?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (flustered) Mine. You follow me again?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yeh. When I saw you at the game, I figured you wanted to see me about something.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I just wanted to see you play.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: How was I?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You looked good, but you oughta open your stance a little. They're pitchin' you inside.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'll try that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I think I oughta tell you that I'm moving in with Tom.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Goin' uptown, huh?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I'm not goin' uptown, I just want to lead a regular life. You know, like an adult maybe. With a house and a garden and normal hours.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You think I can't lead a regular life?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You like the life you've had, Jake. You like hangin' out with the boys, livin' in hotels, eatin' dinner at midnight, having girls send you their underwear in the mail. Remember the surprise party I threw for you when you made the All-Star team? You never showed up, but the doorbell rang once and we all got quiet and hid behind the furniture. It was a guy to serve you with a paternity suit.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That was a hoax. The girl was just trying to get some publicity.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Yes, but you had obviously been with her. And it happened in front of all our friends.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I was drownin', Lynn. The endorsements were dryin' up, my knees were goin', they were talkin' about sendin' me down. I was just trying to hold on to somethin', prove to myself I was still an All-Star. I don't care about that anymore. I know I don't have much time left in baseball. I'm just a guy trying to put his life back together. Thinkin' about you was the only thing that kept me goin' in Mexico.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I've come back to you too many times, Jake. I can't afford to believe you anymore.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess this is our last hurrah then.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I guess so. Did you really read "Moby Dick?"
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Cover to cover.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: When's the wedding?

dialogue.raw_text: October third.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Your mom and dad like this guy?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You're still their favorite.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Gonna be a big wedding?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Tom doesn't like big weddings. You coulda read Plot Outlines of 101 Great Novels.

dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: At any library.

dialogue.raw_text: I mean the wedding.

dialogue.raw_text: Nice church.

dialogue.raw_text: To the wedding.

dialogue.raw_text: If you want. Maybe you really did read it.

direction.raw_text: Taylor wakens and turns over to find Lynn gone. He looks around but there's no sign of her.

direction.raw_text: Taylor comes down the steps, gets in his car, and drives OUT OF FRAME. We HOLD on the SHOT, and...

direction.raw_text: Taylor's car pulls INTO FRAME. He gets out and goes up the steps. There's one light on in the apartment window. Taylor comes up to the door and knocks. Getting no answer, he pushes it open to find that the apartment is completely empty. Just bare hardwood floor. Taylor stands forlorn in the center of the room a beat, then walks on out, switching off the overhead light as he goes.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Donovan is present once again. Rachel does not look pleased.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, my worst fears have been confirmed. We're 60 and 60, nine games out of first, and only two out of the first division. Who do those guys think they are?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Maybe you just have to accept the fact that they're not as bad as you'd hoped.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't have to accept anything. Our attendance is only beginning to rise. If we can force a losing streak for a week or two, we can still turn this thing around. The fans are used to losers here. At the first sign of a slump they'll give up on this team.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's left to do? You've taken away everything you can.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not everything.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Complete with all the luxuries of the average school bus. Temple is looking at a memo from Rachel Phelps.

dialogue.raw_text: Good thing we don't play anybody in Europe.

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know if we can survive any more of these economy measures.

direction.raw_text: We pick up Taylor, Hayes and Vaughn coming into their dilapidated hotel room. Peeling walls and ceilings, rickety furniture, rusted bathroom fixtures. Taylor sprawls down on one of the cots. It collapses on the floor in a cloud of dust.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn is on the mound warming up.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn finishes his warmups. As Taylor pumps the ball down to second, Vaughn hears a voice from the Yankee dug-out.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn glances over and sees that one of the Yankees is dressed in a striped prison uniform. He also wears long earrings, high heels, and of course, glasses. Vaughn tries to ignore the guy, but his concentration is broken. Vaughn steps up on the rubber for his first pitch. He winds and fires. The Yankee LEADOFF HITTER rips a one-hopper to the wall in right center. Hayes runs it down and guns it back to the infield to hold the guy to a double. The convict whoops it up. Vaughn gets back up on the rubber. As he comes to the stretch, he catches sight of the convict again. The guy is doing a pantomime, sneaking up to a car and picking the lock, much to the delight of his teammates. Vaughn throws his pitch in the dirt and all the way to the backstop. The runner on second goes to third.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn gets ready again. The convict finishes picking the lock and then is suddenly arrested. He puts his hands against the wall and spreads his legs for a weapons check, cracking up the whole bench. Vaughn is getting a little steamed. His next pitch is hammered into left for a single, scoring a run.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) So, Ricky Vaughn, roughed up in his only other appearance against the Yankees, will see what he can do with the Bronx Bombers this time. Vaughn, after a slow start, has come on lately and now leads the American League in strikeouts with 221.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Hey, jailbird!
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (throwing the ball back) C'mon, Rick baby, settle down.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: S OF VAUGHN throwing pitches, followed by:
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: of the THIRD HITTER lining a double down the right field line, the FOURTH HITTER a triple off the center field wall, and the FIFTH HITTER a single to right. The scoreboard now reads 4 to 0 Yankees. Taylor comes out to talk to Vaughn.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Vaughn nods as Taylor trots back behind the plate. Vaughn gets set again as his old nemesis, Haywood, steps into the batter's box. Haywood has a sly smile on his face. As Vaughn comes to his stretch, the convict goes back into his act. He's in jail now, struggling against the bars. Finally he bends over and grabs his ankles, while one of his teammates humps up against him, pretending to bugger him. This sends the Yankee bench into hysterics. Vaughn has lost it now. He fires to the plate and Haywood creams another tape measure job into the upper deck. Hayes doesn't even bother to run back to the wall. He just watches it go. 6-0 Yankees.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Brown makes his way to the mound to take Vaughn out.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: What's the problem, Rick? You're throwin' basketballs up there. That guy in the dugout botherin' you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Naw, I'm all right.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Forget him. Worry about the guys carryin' bats. C'mon, Ricky, let's get nasty.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I thought now that Vaughn had some control, he was ready for the Yankees.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Not quite yet.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (V.O.) So, Vaughn pitches in some tough luck here as the Yankees put together as few squib hits and take a 6-0 lead.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: in the press box. The stadium below is empty, the grounds crew covering the infield.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Well, the Indians made a gallant comeback today, but fell one run short as the Yankees held on for a 6- 5 victory, although they didn't do squat after the first inning. Anyway, if the bus makes it here from the hotel we'll be on at 7:30 tomorrow night. Till then, this is Harry Doyle, saying so long, everybody, and Happy Hunting.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: Brown is alone in the bar having a drink. A figure sits down on the stool next to him. It's Donovan.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: On Brown's incredulous face, we...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: Mind if I join you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: (surprised to see him) Donovan. Hell no. What are you doin' here?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Just wanted to get out on the road. You damn near pulled one out today.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Someday we'll figure out how to beat those guys.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ya know, you've done a helluva job this year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Sixty and sixty-one is hardly a helluva job.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: With this club it is.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Ya know, when I first got to camp I figured this team had no chance. I was just hopin' we'd win enough that I could stay on and really start to build something here. But there's a lotta talent on this club, Charlie. The veterans are starting to play back to form and the rookies are developing faster than I thought. There's two or three potential all- stars in there. I think we're a first division team right now.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: You really believe that, don't you?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I know it. All we need is something to bring it all together.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Rachel Phelps would never allow that.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What do you mean?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She doesn't want you in the first division. She doesn't even want you in Cleveland.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: The players are all gathered around, obviously having been called together by Brown.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We take several CUTS OF FACES around the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor, Vaughn, Hayes, Dorn, and the others can hardly believe what they're hearing.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Silence descends on the room.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Taylor surveys the bowed heads around the room. He stands to address the group.
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: Eyes dart around the room, then come back to Taylor. No hands are raised...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: We take CUTS of the startled faces of the players. As the idea sinks in, they begin to come to life. MUSIC begins and we're into a...
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: (addressing the group) I got somethin' I think you oughta know about. I wouldn't have known about it myself if Charlie Donovan hadn't told me, although I shoulda guessed it from everything that's happened. It seems that Mrs. Phelps doesn't think too highly of our worth.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She put this team together because she thought we'd be bad enough to finish dead last, knockin' attendance down to the point where she could move the team to Miami. (pause) And get rid of all of us for better personnel.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even me?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Even you, Dorn.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: In other words, Phelps thinks we're all dinks. That we don't belong in the big leagues.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: That's about it.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What if we don't finish last?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: She'll replace you with somebody who will. After this season, you'll all be sent back to the minors or given your outright release. (pause) So, all we're gonna get is this one year.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: I don't know about the rest of you, but I've been playin' baseball since I was five years old. I've had some good years and some years to forget. I've burned out my knees... I don't think I have three fingers that work right... I've lost most of the money I made and baseball has messed up my personal life from time to time. But I know one thing... I can still play this game a little. And I'd like to know who in this room thinks they're the kinda bum Mrs. Phelps is lookin' for?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Well, then, I guess there's only one thing to do.
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: What's that?
dialogue.name: dialogue

dialogue.raw_text: Win the whole fuckin' thing.
dialogue.name: dialogue

direction.raw_text: detailing the newly-motivated Indians' drive for the pennant and the "Pennant Fever" it creates in Cleveland. We begin with...
direction.name: direction

direction.raw_text: hanging a full size blowup of Rachel Phelps on the locker room wall. In the picture she's pointing as if out at the players, and a bubble above her head says, "YOU GUYS STINK!" A set of designer clothes, of the type Rachel wears, have been superimposed on the picture. The clothes are divided into 32 pull-off squares.
direction.name: direction

dialogue.raw_text: I figure it's gonna take 32 more victories to win this thing. Every time we win, we peel a square.
dialogue.name: dialogue

Vaughn catches the ball and rifles a throw down to Taylor, who puts the tag on the sliding Hayes. Cerrano, who's umping, calls Hayes out. Hayes jumps up and argues vociferously, hopping around in frustration.
